Steve, I have no solid evidence about the NEAT performance 
ramifications o=
f going either way.  From all I've seen, they perform 
about the same.  But=
 the caveat is that the only task I really ever 
used the in-order method o=
n was pole balancing, which can be solved 
by a shallow network.  So it's s=
till possible that it would be worse 
in highly recurrent tasks with deep n=
etworks, since less activation 
travels over the recurrent connections per =
pass through the 
network.  That would be my main concern.

On the other ha=
nd, in strictly feed-forward tasks there should be no 
difference at all.

=
By the way, I think the way I do activation in NEAT is "standard" 
for arbi=
trary-topology neural networks (like large meshes in 
cortical simulations)=
.  In such systems order is often pretty 
ambiguous.  So that is another an=
gle you could use to decide which 
way to go- is there a real benefit to di=
verging from a kind of 
standard that people expect?

ken

ogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:

fore seeing your reply.

> understand your preference.  I'm wondering =

tion to use less 
CPU,

ks grow in size.

to

are of it
